key_insight: ImmunoStruct integrates sequence, 3D structure, and biochemical properties into a single multimodal deep-learning model to predict immunogenicity. The model produces interpretable attributions that help generate mechanistic hypotheses about why molecules trigger immune responses.
problem_solved: Predicting immunogenicity requires combining diverse molecular information (primary sequence, tertiary structure and physicochemical features) and providing interpretable explanations — a gap that prevents reliable screening and hypothesis-driven design in therapeutics and vaccines.
method: Separate encoders extract representations from amino-acid sequence, 3D structural embeddings, and computed biochemical features.
A multimodal fusion module integrates these representations and feeds them to a prediction head that outputs immunogenicity scores.
An interpretability layer (e.g., attention/attribution maps) links predictions back to specific residues, structural motifs, or physicochemical signals to support hypothesis generation.
impact: For ML practitioners this demonstrates how multimodal architectures can improve biological prediction tasks while preserving interpretability, enabling more informed molecule prioritization and targeted experimental follow-up.

paper_title: ImmunoStruct enables multimodal deep learning for immunogenicity prediction
paper_authors: Kevin Bijan Givechian, João Felipe Rocha, Chen Liu, Edward Yang, Sidharth Tyagi
